channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israeli Strike in Gaza Kills 18, Officials Say, Including 6 U.N. Workers
item.description: While resuming its offensive against militants in the West Bank, Israel also kept up its bombardment of the Gaza Strip, striking a school building used as a shelter for displaced people.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers during a raid on Wednesday in Tulkarm, in the West Bank.

item.title: Alberto Fujimori, Ex-Leader of Peru Imprisoned for Rights Abuses, Dies at 86
item.description: During his decade in power, he revived the economy and crushed two violent leftist insurgencies. But he was forced out in a corruption scandal and later imprisoned for human rights abuses.
item.dc:creator: Sewell Chan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Alberto Fujimori, left, Peru’s president from 1990 to 2000, at a military celebration in 1998 that honored the country’s independence.

item.title: Defying Protests, Mexico’s Senate Approves Judicial Overhaul
item.description: The chamber’s approval clears away the last major hindrance to the sweeping proposals championed by the president, which have prompted nationwide strikes.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Senate in Mexico City on Tuesday night, protesting legislation that would dramatically change Mexico’s judiciary.

item.title: Islamists Gain in Jordan, Reflecting Public Anger Over Gaza War
item.description: The political arm of the Muslim Brotherhood won a sizable share of seats in Parliament, though not enough to challenge the government’s pro-Western tilt.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Rana F. Sweis
item.media:description: A voter arriving to cast her ballot in Amman on Tuesday.

item.title: Blinken Visits Kyiv During Precarious Moment in Ukraine War and U.S. Politics
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his British counterpart, David Lammy, made a rare joint trip to Ukraine to show allied solidarity as the American presidential election looms.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, center, walking beside his British counterpart, David Lammy, as they arrived via train in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Debate Puts Trump’s Affinity for Putin Back in the Spotlight
item.description: The former president’s refusal to back Ukraine’s war effort showed the likely limits of U.S. support for Kyiv if he returns to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas pipe explosion from a Russian missile strike on Kharkiv, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: U.K.’s Revered NHS Is in Deep Trouble, Darzi Report Finds
item.description: A government-commissioned review into the National Health Service laid bare the challenge Prime Minister Keir Starmer faces after years of underinvestment.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The emergency room at Queen’s Hospital in Romford, England, last year. A new report said the National Health Service had been “starved of capital.”

item.title: 4 Climbers Are Found Dead on Mont Blanc in the French Alps
item.description: The climbers from Italy and South Korea were found on Tuesday after they went missing three days earlier during a period of bad weather on the peak.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: There have been several deaths this year on Mont Blanc, where climate change and overcrowding have contributed to adverse conditions for climbers.

item.title: Donald Sheppard, British D-Day Veteran, Dies at 104
item.description: He helped liberate Bergen-Belsen, the Nazi concentration camp where Anne Frank had died.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Iran’s New President Visits Iraq, Tending to an Old Alliance
item.description: In a region in turmoil, Tehran’s ties to its neighbor are more important than ever.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: A handout photo from the Iraqi prime minister’s press office showing Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani of Iraq, left, and President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran, center, in Baghdad on Wednesday.

item.title: Violence Resurges in Manipur, Indian State Locked in Bloody Conflict for 16 Months
item.description: Ethnic tensions have turned Manipur into an open war zone. Struggling to contain the unrest, the authorities have reimposed a curfew and internet blackout.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: Security forces fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Imphal, a city in the northeastern Indian state of Manipur, on Tuesday.

item.title: Family of American Woman Held in China for 10 Years Asks for Help
item.description: Dawn Michelle Hunt, who is serving a life sentence, says she was duped into carrying drugs. Her family says she is seriously ill and should be sent home.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl

item.title: French Prime Minister Barnier Takes Out Differences With Macron
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s newly picked prime minister wasted no time in putting a pointed distance between himself and France’s weakened leader.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: France’s new prime minister, Michel Barnier, center, at a hospital in Paris on Saturday. It was his first official visit in his new role.

item.title: Should Ukraine Launch Western Weapons Deep Into Russia?
item.description: President Biden has refused to allow Ukraine to use long-range Western missiles on Russian military targets, but he appears to be wavering.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian rescue workers carrying a man injured in a Russian missile strike on a sports complex in Kharkiv, Ukraine earlier this month.

item.title: Mexico Is Split on Judicial Overhaul as Plan Inches Toward Becoming Law
item.description: Even as a sweeping proposal to elect nearly 7,000 judges inches toward law, some Mexicans have protested it. Others welcomed the chance to vote in judges.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, James Wagner and Marian Carrasquero
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside of the Senate in Mexico City on Tuesday.

item.title: After Being Shot, Slovakia’s Leader Targets His Enemies
item.description: Prime Minister Robert Fico has purged prosecutors, cultural officials, journalists and others he believes fueled “hatred and aggression” against him.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Robert Fico in July. The Slovakian leader, who has been purging his opponents from a wide range of institutions, survived an assassination attempt in May.

item.title: Deepfake Sex Videos in South Korea Seen as Old Misogyny With New Tech
item.description: Men in chat rooms have been victimizing women they know by putting their faces on pornographic clips. Some Korean women say the only thing new about it is the technology.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A protest against deepfake pornography in Seoul last week.

item.title: Citing Gaza Help, Blinken Waives Human Rights Conditions on Aid to Egypt
item.description: Cairo will receive its full military aid allotment of $1.3 billion after the secretary of state also said it had made progress on releasing political prisoners and protecting Americans.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The decision by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was based on Egypt’s monthslong role as an intermediary between Hamas and Israel as the two sides negotiate an elusive cease-fire deal.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Who Won the Harris-Trump Debate?
item.description: Plus, a video game provokes outrage.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: North Korean Missiles Rain Down on Ukraine Despite Sanctions
item.description: Russia has received new shipments of Hwasong-11 short-range ballistic missiles, according to a new report.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: Part of the tail section of a North Korean Hwasong-11 short-range ballistic missile examined by weapons investigators in Kyiv on Jan. 11.

item.title: The No. 1 Breaker in the World Is … Raygun?
item.description: The Australian breaker who was mocked at the Olympics for her kangaroo-hopping routine is now atop the official world rankings. Here’s how it happened.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Raygun, the world’s greatest breaker, apparently.

item.title: Where Do Trump and Harris Stand on Israel-Gaza Conflict?
item.description: The war in Gaza merited a few scant mentions in the presidential debate. Here’s a look at where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Watching the debate between Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Says He Is ‘Outraged’ Over Killing of American Activist in West Bank
item.description: In his first extensive remarks on the death of Aysenur Eygi, the U.S. president called for accountability from Israel.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Mourners took part in a funeral procession for Aysenur Eygi in Nablus in the occupied West Bank on Monday.

item.title: Death Toll in Vietnam From Typhoon Yagi Rises to 143
item.description: Days after the storm made landfall, northern Vietnam was being battered by incessant rain. A landslide buried a whole village in a mountainous province.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Yagi was the strongest typhoon to hit Vietnam in decades. Several neighborhoods in the capital, Hanoi, flooded.

item.title: Why Nearly All Judges in Mexico Could Soon Be Chosen by Voters
item.description: The legislation passed by Congress could produce one of the most far-reaching judicial overhauls in any major democracy.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judiciary workers protesting the contentious legislation last month in front of the Supreme Court in Mexico City.

item.title: Cholera Deaths Soar Worldwide Despite Being Easily Preventable
item.description: Fatalities spiked 71 percent last year, far outpacing the 13 percent rise in cases, the World Health Organization said.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A patient in an isolation tent being treated for cholera last year in Malawi. The spread of the disease there was driven by catastrophic weather events.

item.title: Israeli Bombing in Gaza Humanitarian Zone Kills at Least 19, Officials Say
item.description: The Israeli airstrike, which the military said targeted Hamas militants, appeared to use 2,000-pound bombs, which Israel has been criticized for using in heavily populated areas.
item.dc:creator: Rawan Sheikh Ahmad, Ephrat Livni, Sanjana Varghese and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: The site of Israeli strikes on a makeshift camp for internally displaced Palestinians in Al-Mawasi, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Guide to the Harris-Trump Debate
item.description: Plus, the great films of James Earl Jones.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: The debate will be hosted by ABC News from Philadelphia.

item.title: I.C.C. Prosecutor Presses Court for Arrest Warrants for Hamas Chiefs and Israeli Leaders
item.description: The prosecutor, Karim Khan, asked the court to make its decision on the warrants with the “utmost urgency” because of “the worsening situation in Palestine.”
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Karim Khan, the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague, initially requested the arrest warrants in May.

item.title: K-Cup Pods Aren’t Recyclable, S.E.C. Says
item.description: The agency said Keurig, in its financial filings, had claimed its pods could be “effectively recycled” but didn’t note that two big recycling companies wouldn’t accept them.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: There has been a long debate over the environmental effects of single-serving coffee and tea pods.

item.title: ‘You Do Need to Tell a Story’: Prime Minister Keir Starmer Survives Revolt Over Winter Fuel Aid
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer survived a test of his authority, but more than 50 Labour lawmakers did not back his plan to reduce fuel aid.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain speaking on Tuesday in Brighton.

item.title: White House and WADA in Bitter Fight Over Chinese Doping Cases
item.description: World Anti-Doping Agency officials, furious at U.S. investigations into the handling of positive tests, have sought to exclude a Biden administration representative from its board meetings.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja, Michael S. Schmidt and Jenny Vrentas
item.category: White House Office of National Drug Control Policy
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rahul Gupta, the director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, represents not only the United States but more than 40 countries in the Americas as a member of WADA’s executive board.

item.title: Israeli Military Reveals Brutal Conditions 6 Hostages Endured in a Gaza Tunnel
item.description: The hostages, whose bodies were recently recovered, appear to have spent the last weeks of their lives in a tight and humid tunnel about 20 meters underground.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Photos in Tel Aviv of the six hostages whose bodies were recently found in a tunnel in Gaza.

item.title: 2,000-Pound Bombs Likely Used in Al-Mawasi Strike
item.description: The large size of the two craters left in the aftermath of the attack suggest that Israel used the powerful bombs, according to experts and a New York Times analysis.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese, Malachy Browne and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:description: Large craters at the site of an Israeli strike on Al-Mawasi, an area of the southern Gaza Strip, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump and Democrats Agree: U.S. Needs a National Wealth Fund for Investments
item.description: Donald Trump has suggested he wants one, and the White House indicated that it has been quietly working on a proposal to set one up.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump said a sovereign wealth fund would generate so much profit that it would help pay down the national debt.

item.title: Pakistani Police Arrest Lawmakers Allied With Imran Khan
item.description: In an overnight raid on the Parliament, police arrested at least 10 members of Khan’s party, deepening the political battle between the imprisoned ex-leader and the country’s powerful military.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Gohar Khan, chairman of jailed former Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan’s political party, addressed the media outside court following his release in Islamabad on Tuesday.

item.title: In Jordan’s Election, Unemployment, Rather Than Gaza, Is on Voters’ Minds
item.description: The Muslim Brotherhood has campaigned on opposition to the Gaza war, but analysts say it won’t be as decisive a factor in parliamentary elections as high unemployment.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Rana F. Sweis
item.media:description: A woman leaving a polling station after voting in parliamentary elections in al-Fuhais, a town near Jordan’s capital, Amman, on Tuesday.

item.title: Singles in Spain Look for Love in the Grocery Store, With Pineapples as Prop
item.description: How the Spanish grocery chain Mercadona got a reputation as an unlikely dating hub, with its upside-down pineapples as props.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler

item.title: Dominique Pelicot, on Trial in Mass Rape Case in France, Taken to Hospital
item.description: Dominique Pelicot, 71, was due to testify on Tuesday over charges he invited dozens of men to his home to abuse his wife, Gisèle Pelicot. His condition was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Béatrice Zavarro, the lawyer for Dominique Pelicot, told journalists at the courthouse in Avignon, France, that he had been suffering from abdominal pain since Friday.

item.title: U.S. Accuses Iran of Sending Ballistic Missiles to Russia
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke in London, where his British counterpart also promised a punitive response. They plan to visit Ukraine together.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: The U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, left, at a joint news conference on Tuesday with Britain’s foreign secretary, David Lammy.

item.title: Israel Says Its Forces Likely Shot Slain American Unintentionally
item.description: The Israeli military said the killing of Aysenur Eygi in the occupied West Bank was unintentional. The top U.S. diplomat said the shooting was “not acceptable,” and Israel’s conduct must change.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A funeral for Aysenur Eygi in the city of Nablus in the occupied West Bank on Monday.

item.title: The Spectator Magazine Sold to Paul Marshall, a U.K. Hedge Fund Tycoon
item.description: Paul Marshall, a multimillionaire founder and investor in upstart conservative media outlets, has bought the right-wing British magazine in a deal worth about $131 million.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler

item.title: Tariq Ramadan, Scholar of Islam, Is Convicted of Rape in Switzerland
item.description: An appeals court in Geneva overturned a previous acquittal and found Tariq Ramadan guilty. He faces separate charges in France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Tariq Ramadan leaving court in Geneva in May. He experienced a rapid fall from grace in 2017 and 2018 after several women accused him of sexual assault in the early days of the #MeToo movement.

item.title: Man Who Set on Fire Olympic Runner Rebecca Cheptegei Dies
item.description: Dickson Ndiema died from injuries he sustained when he set Rebecca Cheptegei, his partner, on fire. The police had planned to charge him with murder.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Isabella Kwai and Jimmy Gitaka
item.media:description: Rebecca Cheptegei during the World Athletics Championship in Budapest, Hungary last year.

item.title: Polio Vaccinations Begin in Northern Gaza After Israel Detained a UN Convoy
item.description: The U.N. said that Israeli forces had held staff members at gunpoint for several hours. The Israeli military said that it had intelligence suggesting there were “Palestinian suspects” with the convoy.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Anushka Patil
item.media:description: A line for polio vaccinations in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Fearing Airstrikes, Gaza School Shelters Try to Bar Hamas and Others
item.description: Residents, already forced to flee their homes by intense bombardment, want to avoid becoming a target for Israeli forces hunting Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Checking a school housing displaced people that was hit during Israeli bombardment in Nuseirat, in the central Gaza Strip, in June.

item.title: Ali Mohamed Kibao, Tanzania Opposition Official, Found Dead
item.description: Ali Mohamed Kibao was beaten and acid had been poured on his face, according to an autopsy, his party said.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Supporters of Tanzania’s main opposition party, Chadema, protested in Dar es Salaam in January.

item.title: Hostages Still Held by Hamas Are in ‘Grave Danger,’ Families Warn
item.description: Six hostages who were found dead in Gaza recently had been held in narrow tunnels and suffered from malnutrition, family members said, citing an Israeli military investigation.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Andrey Kozlov, a Russian Israeli hostage rescued from Gaza, spoke near Israel’s military headquarters in Tel Aviv on Saturday, at a protest calling for a cease-fire and the release of Israeli hostages.

item.title: What to Know About the FGC-9 and Other 3-D-Printed Guns
item.description: Homemade firearms are spreading faster than governments can keep up. For many gun designers, that’s the idea.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A 3D-printed gun called the Liberator in Austin, Texas, in 2018.

item.title: ‘Ivan the Troll’ Has Made a 3-D-Printed Gun, the FGC-9, Go Viral
item.description: From his Illinois home, he champions guns for all. The Times confirmed his real name and linked the firearm he helped design to terrorists, drug dealers and freedom fighters in at least 15 countries.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: via Koblenz Public Prosecutor's Office, Germany
item.media:description: Parts of an FGC-9 homemade firearm seized in Germany in July 2021.

item.title: These Venezuelan Election Observers Got Death Threats. Now They’re in Hiding.
item.description: The New York Times spoke to several election volunteers for Venezuela’s opposition party who found that Edmundo González defeated Nicolás Maduro in July. They fled the country after facing death threats from Maduro’s supporters.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pena, Alexandra Vivas and Ben Laffin

item.title: Australia Plans to Set Age Limits for Social Media
item.description: The government is considering setting a minimum age for platforms like TikTok and Instagram that could be as high as 16.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I want kids to have a childhood. I want them off their devices and onto the footy field and onto the netball courts,” said Australia’s prime minister, Anthony Albanese.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Russia With Large Drone Attack, Killing 1 Person
item.description: A woman in the capital region was killed during the attack, officials said. Russian air defenses shot down 20 drones around Moscow and almost 150 nationwide, according to the Defense Ministry.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A damaged building in the Moscow area after a Ukrainian drone attack on Tuesday.

item.title: How Nail Salons Lift Morale in Ukraine
item.description: In Ukraine, even a visit for a manicure, which often involves navigating power outages and air-raid sirens, can turn into an act of defiance.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoria Gulieva, 30, accompanied by her Pomeranian dog, having a pedicure at a nail salon in Kyiv, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: Airstrikes Hit Syrian City Said to Be a Weapons Research Hub, Killing 18
item.description: Syria accused Israel of carrying out the attacks in and around Masyaf, where experts say missiles and unconventional weapons are developed. Israel did not comment.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ephrat Livni and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A vehicle damaged in an airstrike, on the outskirts of Masyaf, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump and Harris Prepare to Debate
item.description: Plus, is it A.I. or real life?
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: The debate stands to be the most important night in Kamala Harris’s political career.

item.title: How a Philippine Televangelist Ended Up on the F.B.I.’s Most-Wanted List
item.description: Here is what to know about the powerful doomsday preacher Apollo Carreon Quiboloy and his arrest.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Apollo Carreon Quiboloy in 2016.
